page.title: United States women's national under-17 soccer team

revisions.rev:
{{Infobox national football team | Name = United States U-17 Women's National Team | Badge = | Nickname = ''The Yanks''
''The Stars and Stripes''
''The Red, White, and Blue'' | Association = [[United States Soccer Federation]] | Confederation = [[CONCACAF]] ([[North America]]) | FIFA Trigramme = USA | Coach = {{flagicon|USA}} [[Albertin Montoya]] | Asst Manager = | Captain = | Most caps = | Top scorer = | FIFA Rank = | FIFA max = | FIFA max date = | FIFA min = | FIFA min date = | pattern_la1 = _left_usa2 | pattern_b1 = _USAF2 | pattern_ra1 = _right_usa2 | leftarm1 = FFFFFF | body1 = FFFFFF | rightarm1 = FFFFFF | shorts1 = FFFFFF | socks1 = FFFFFF | pattern_la2 = _left_usa1 | pattern_b2 = _USAF1 | pattern_ra2 = _right_usa1 | leftarm2 = FFFFFF | body2 = FFFFFF | rightarm2 = FFFFFF | shorts2 = 002868 | socks2 = 002868 | First game = | Largest win = | Largest loss = | U17WC apps = 1 | U17WC first = [[2008 FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup|2008]] | U17WC best = Runners-up ([[2008 FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup|2008]]) | | type=women}} The '''United States U-17 women's national soccer team''' is a youth [[association football|soccer]] team operated under the auspices of [[United States Soccer Federation|U.S. Soccer]]. Its primary role is the development of players in preparation for the full [[United States women's national soccer team|Women's National Team]]. The team's most recent major tournament was the [[2008 FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup]], in which the United States team finished runners-up to tournament champions [[Korea DPR women's national football team|North Korea]]. The team competes in a variety of competitions, including the biennial [[FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup]], which is the top competition for this age group. The current head coach is [[Albertin Montoya]]. ==History== ===2002 through 2005=== The women's U-17 program was started in 2002 and was initially focused on developing players for the [[United States U-20 women's national soccer team|U-19 national team]]. The U-17s played their first matches in November 2002, including a 3-0 victory over [[Scotland women's national football team|Scotland]]. Through 2003, the U-17s went undefeated in international matches, defeating youth teams from [[Canada women's national soccer team|Canada]] and [[Germany women's national football team|Germany]], and repeated that feat in 2004. In 2005, however, the U-17s suffered defeats in matches against the Canadian and [[Mexico women's national football team|Mexican]] youth teams. In 2006, the U-17s competed against various youth teams from [[Argentina women's national football team|Argentina]] and Germany, including a loss to the senior [[Argentina women's national football team|Argentina women's national team]].[http://www.ussoccer.com/Teams/Youth/US-Under17-Women/About-the-Team.aspx About the Team], US Soccer. ===2007=== In February 2007, [[FIFA]] began organizing for the inaugural [[FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup]] in [[New Zealand]].[http://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/u17womensworldcup/newzealand2008/releases/newsid=636414.html#fifa+looks+forward+competitions+chile+new+zealand FIFA looks forward to the competitions in Chile and New Zealand], FIFA.com. In preparation for the tournament, the U-17s posted a 9-1-0 record, defeating U-17 teams from Germany and [[Uruguay women's national football team|Uruguay]] and U-19 teams from [[Denmark women's national football team|Denmark]], [[England women's national football team|England]], and Argentina.[http://www.ussoccer.com/Teams/Youth/US-Under17-Women/About-the-Team.aspx About the Team], US Soccer. ===2008=== The U-17s compiled a record of 19-3-2 and 11-2-1 in international matches, winning the [[CONCACAF Women's U-17 Championship]] in [[Trinidad & Tobago]] on July 26, 2008, defeating [[Costa Rica women's national soccer team|Costa Rica]] 4-1.[http://www.concacaf.com/page/WUnder17s/HistoricalStats/0,,12813,00.html Women's U17 2008 Schedule], CONCACAF official website. At the [[2008 FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup]], the United States lost their opening match to [[Japan women's national football team|Japan]]. They scraped through the opening rounds of play with a draw against [[France women's national football team|France]], and advanced through the tournament to the final, where they lost in overtime to [[Korea DPR women's national football team|North Korea]]. [[Taylor Vancil]] was named the best [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] at the tournament.[http://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/u17womensworldcup/newzealand2008/news/newsid=948160.html#perfect+tens+strike+gold Perfect tens strike gold], FIFA.com Out of the 13 goals that the USA had at the tournament, only three players actually scored them: [[Vicki DiMartino]] (5), [[Courtney Verloo]] (4), and [[Kristen Mewis]] (2). The other two goals were [[own goal]]s by [[Paraguay women's national football team|Paraguay]] and [[Korea DPR women's national football team|North Korea]].[http://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/u17womensworldcup/newzealand2008/teams/team=1916472/statistics.html 2008 FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup Statistics: USA], FIFA.com. ===2010=== The U-17s were favored to win the [[2010 CONCACAF Women's U-17 Championship]] held in [[Costa Rica]], winning their group and scoring 32 goals. However, they suffered a stunning loss to [[Canada women's national football team|Canada]] in the semifinals, on a [[Penalty shootout (association football)|penalty shootout]]. This loss prevented the United States from qualifying to the [[2010 FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup]], the first time in history that a United States women's national soccer team has not advanced out of their region to a Women's World Cup. ==FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup Record== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- !Year !Result !Matches !Wins !Draws !Losses !GF !GA |- bgcolor=silver
